dublin_core.dcvalue: Burn wound photography has diverse clinical applications however inherent technological limitations mitigate its utility Limitations include lack of quality control serial imaging complexity and expense With the performance gap between smart devices and digital cameras rapidly narrowing and computing performance increasing smart devices are poised to uniquely address these limitations and enhance the field of wound photography To this end we developed a proof of concept smart device application addressing the limitations of traditional photography and meeting the needs of burn clinicians The result was an innovative smart device application providing user friendly serial imaging and informatics capabilities at the patient bedside The application generated images with significantly higher brightness 2 4 1 07 vs 3 8 1 69 n 15 pUnder0 05 and higher contrast 255 0 00 vs 236 3 5 64 n 15 pUnder0 0001 more consistent positioning 1 22 0 03 vs 2 08 0 61 n 15 pUnder0 0001 and zoom 18 14 vs 14 29 n 15 pUnder0 0001 compared to those taken by a basic compact digital camera using default settings Surveyed clinician end users reported greater functionality 20 vs 0 n 20 pUnder0 001 and a more intuitive interface 18 vs 2 n 20 pUnder0 001 with the application We report consistent serial wound imaging and informatics are both feasible on a smart device platform These findings will pave the way for new smart device based clinical applications

Development of novel smart device based application for serial wound imaging and management.
